pages.title: Ten-of-diamonds decahedron
pages.text:
{{technical|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox polyhedron |image=File:Ten-of-diamonds_decahedron_skew.png |type= |faces=8 [[triangle]]s
2 [[rhombi]] |edges=16 |vertices=8 |symmetry=[[Point groups in three dimensions|D2d]], order 8 |dual=Skew-truncated tetragonal disphenoid |properties=space-filling |net=File:Ten-of-diamonds_decahedron_net.png }} In [[geometry]], the '''ten-of-diamonds decahedron''' is a [[space-filling polyhedron]] with 10 faces, 2 opposite rhombi with orthogonal major axes, connected by 8 identical [[isosceles triangle]] faces. Although it is convex, it is not a [[Johnson solid]] because its faces are not composed entirely of regular polygons. Michael Goldberg references it by the [[playing card]] name, ''ten-of-diamonds'', as a 10-faced polyhedron with two opposite [[rhombus|rhombic]] (diamond-shaped) faces. He catalogued it in a 1982 paper as 10-II, the second in a list of 26 known space-filling decahedra.Goldberg, Michael. ''On the Space-filling Decahedra''. Structural Topology, 1982, num. Type 10-II [https://upcommons.upc.edu/handle/2099/990] ==Coordinates == If the space-filling polyhedron is placed in a 3-D coordinate grid, the coordinates for the 8 vertices can be given as: (0, ±2, −1), (±2, 0, 1), (±1, 0, −1), (0, ±1, 1). :[[File:Ten-of-diamonds_decahedron_in_cube.png|160px]] == Symmetry == The ''ten-of-diamonds'' has D2d symmetry, which projects as order-4 dihedral (square) symmetry in two dimensions. It can be seen as a [[triakis tetrahedron]], with two pairs of coplanar triangles merged into rhombic faces. The dual is similar to a [[truncated tetrahedron]], except two edges from the original tetrahedron are reduced to zero length making pentagonal faces. The dual polyhedra can be called a skew-truncated tetragonal disphenoid, where 2 edges along the symmetry axis completely truncated down to the edge midpoint. {| class=wikitable width=400 |+ Symmetric projection |- !colspan=2|Ten of diamonds !Related !colspan=2|Dual !Related |- align=center valign=top |[[File:Ten-of-diamonds_decahedron_solid.png|120px]]
Solid faces |[[File:Ten-of-diamonds_decahedron_frame.png|120px]]
Edges |[[File:Dual tetrahedron t01.png|120px]]
[[triakis tetrahedron]] |[[File:Dual-ten-of-diamonds-solid.png|120px]]
Solid faces |[[File:Dual-ten-of-diamonds-frame.png|120px]]
Edges |[[File:3-simplex t01.svg|120px]]
[[Truncated tetrahedron]] |- align=center |colspan=2|v=8, e=16, f=10 |v=8, e=18, f=12 |colspan=2|v=10, e=16, f=8 |v=12, e=18, f=8 |} == Honeycomb== {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="margin-left:10px" width="240" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Ten-of-diamonds honeycomb |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Schläfli symbol]]||dht1,2{4,3,4} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter–Dynkin diagram|Coxeter diagram]]||{{CDD||node|4|node_fh|3|node_fh|4|node}} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Cell type||Ten-of-diamonds
[[File:Ten-of-diamonds decahedron skew.png|60px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Space group|Space]]
[[Fibrifold notation|Fibrifold]]
[[Coxeter notation#Space groups|Coxeter]]||[[Cubic crystal system|I{{overline|3}} (204)]]
8−o
[[4,3+,4]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Dual||[[Alternated bitruncated cubic honeycomb]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Properties||Cell-transitive |} The ''ten-of-diamonds'' is used in the honeycomb with [[Coxeter diagram]] {{CDD|node|4|node_fh|3|node_fh|4|node}}, being the dual of an [[alternated bitruncated cubic honeycomb]], {{CDD|node|4|node_h|3|node_h|4|node}}. Since the ''alternated bitruncated cubic honeycomb'' fills space by [[pyritohedral icosahedron|pyritohedral icosahedra]], {{CDD|node|4|node_h|3|node_h}}, and [[tetragonal disphenoid]]al tetrahedra, [[vertex figure]]s of this honeycomb are their duals – [[pyritohedra]], {{CDD|node|4|node_fh|3|node_fh}} and [[tetragonal disphenoid]]s. Cells can be seen as the cells of the [[tetragonal disphenoid honeycomb]], {{CDD|node|4|node_f1|3|node_f1|4|node}}, with alternate cells removed and augmented into neighboring cells by a center vertex. The rhombic faces in the honeycomb are aligned along 3 orthogonal planes. {| class=wikitable width=500 !Uniform !Dual !Alternated !colspan=2|Dual alternated |- !{{CDD|node|4|node_1|3|node_1|4|node}}
t1,2{4,3,4} !{{CDD|node|4|node_f1|3|node_f1|4|node}}
dt1,2{4,3,4} !{{CDD|node|4|node_h|3|node_h|4|node}}
ht1,2{4,3,4} !colspan=2|{{CDD|node|4|node_fh|3|node_fh|4|node}}
dht1,2{4,3,4} |- valign=top |[[File:Bitruncated Cubic Honeycomb.svg|137px]]
[[Bitruncated cubic honeycomb]] of [[truncated octahedra]]l cells |[[File:Quartercell honeycomb.png|110px]]
[[tetragonal disphenoid honeycomb]] |[[File:Alternated bitruncated cubic honeycomb.png|107px]]Dual honeycomb of icosahedra and tetrahedra |[[File:Ten-of-diamonds_decahedron_honeycomb.png|139px]]
Ten-of-diamonds honeycomb |[[File:Ten-of-diamonds_decahedron_honeycomb2.png|175px]]
Honeycomb structure orthogonally viewed along cubic plane |} == Related space-filling polyhedra== The ''ten-of-diamonds'' can be dissected in an [[octagon]]al cross-section between the two rhombic faces. It is a decahedron with 12 vertices, 20 edges, and 10 faces (4 [[triangle]]s, 4 [[trapezoid]]s, 1 [[rhombus]], and 1 [[Octagon#Symmetry|isotoxal octagon]]). Michael Goldberg labels this polyhedron 10-XXV, the 25th in a list of space-filling decahedra.''On Space-filling Decahedra'', type 10-XXV. The ''ten-of-diamonds'' can be dissected as a half-model on a symmetry plane into a space-filling [[heptahedron]] with 6 vertices, 11 edges, and 7 faces (6 triangles and 1 trapezoid). Michael Goldberg identifies this polyhedron as a ''triply truncated quadrilateral prism'', type 7-XXIV, the 24th in a list of heptagonal space-fillers.Goldberg, Michael ''On the space-filling heptahedra'' Geometriae Dedicata, June 1978, Volume 7, Issue 2, pp 175–184 [https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00181630] [http://documentslide.com/documents/on-the-space-filling-heptahedra.html PDF] type 7-XXIV It can be further dissected as a quarter-model by another symmetry plane into a space-filling [[hexahedron]] with 6 vertices, 10 edges, and 6 faces (4 triangles, 2 right trapezoids). Michael Goldberg identifies this polyhedron as an ''ungulated quadrilateral pyramid'', type 6-X, the 10th in a list of space-filling hexahedron.Goldberg, Michael ''On the space-filling hexahedra'' Geom. Dedicata, June 1977, Volume 6, Issue 1, pp 99–108 [https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00181585] [http://documentslide.com/documents/on-the-space-filling-hexahedra.html PDF] type 6-X {| class=wikitable width=400 |+ Dissected models in symmetric projections |- align=center !Relation !Decahedral
half model !Heptahedral
half model !Hexahedral
quarter model |- align=center !Symmetry |C2v, order 4 |Cs, order 2 |C2, order 2 |- align=center !Edges |[[File:Cuthalf-ten-of-diamonds-frame.png|160px]] |[[File:Half-ten-of-diamonds-frame.png|160px]] |[[File:Quarter_ten-of-diamonds-frame.png|100px]] |- align=center !Net |[[File:Cuthalf-ten-of-diamonds-net.png|160px]] |[[File:Half-ten-of-diamonds-net.png|160px]] |[[File:Quarter-ten-diamonds-net.png|140px]] |- align=center !Elements |v=12, e=20, f=10 |v=6, e=11, f=7 |v=6, e=10, f=6 |} === Rhombic bowtie === {{Infobox polyhedron |name=Rhombic bowtie |image=File:Double-ten-of-diamonds-solid.png |type= |faces=16 [[triangle]]s
2 [[rhombi]] |edges=28 |vertices=12 |symmetry=[[Point groups in three dimensions|D2h]], order 8 |dual= |properties=space-filling |net=File:Double-ten-of-diamonds-net.png }} Pairs of ''ten-of-diamonds'' can be attached as a nonconvex ''bow-tie'' space-filler, called a '''rhombic bowtie''' for its cross-sectional appearance. The two right-most symmetric projections below show the rhombi edge-on on the top, bottom and a middle ''neck'' where the two halves are connected. The 2D projections can look convex or concave. It has 12 vertices, 28 edges, and 18 faces (16 triangles and 2 rhombi) within D2h symmetry. These paired-cells stack more easily as inter-locking elements. Long sequences of these can be stacked together in 3 axes to fill space.Robert Reid, Anthony Steed [http://www0.cs.ucl.ac.uk/staff/ucacajs/bowtie-5H.pdf Bowties: A Novel Class of Space Filling Polyhedron] 2003 The 12 vertex coordinates in a 2-[[unit cube]]. (further [[Augmentation (geometry)|augmentations]] on the rhombi can be done with 2 unit translation in ''z''.) :(0, ±1, −1), (±1, 0, 0), (0, ±1, 1), :(±1/2, 0, −1), (0, ±1/2, 0), (±1/2, 0, 1) {| class=wikitable width=480 |+ Bow-tie model (two ten-of-diamonds) !Skew||colspan=4|Symmetric |- align=center |[[File:Double-ten-of-diamonds-frame.png|100px]] |[[File:Double-ten-of-diamonds-frame1.png|100px]] |[[File:Double-ten-of-diamonds-frame4.png|100px]] |[[File:Double-ten-of-diamonds-frame2.png|110px]] |[[File:Double-ten-of-diamonds-frame3.png|110px]] |} == See also== * [[Elongated gyrobifastigium]] == References== {{reflist}} * Koch 1972 Koch, Elke, Wirkungsbereichspolyeder und Wirkungsbereichsteilunger zukubischen Gitterkomplexen mit weniger als drei Freiheitsgraden (Efficiency Polyhedra, and Efficiency Dividers, cubic lattice complexes with less than three degrees of freedom) Dissertation, University Marburg/Lahn 1972 - Model 10/8–1, 28–404. [[Category:Space-filling polyhedra]]

6 [[trapezoid]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||24 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||14 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Vertex configuration]]||(2) 4.4.4
(6) 4.4.4.4
(6) 4.4.4 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[List of spherical symmetry groups|Symmetry]]||[[Dihedral symmetry|''D''''3h'']], [3,2], (*322), order 12 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Point_groups_in_three_dimensions#Rotation_groups|Rotation symmetry]]||[[Dihedral symmetry|''D''''3'']], [3,2]+, (322), order 6 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Dual polyhedron]]||[[Triangular orthobicupola]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Properties||[[convex set|convex]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Net (polyhedron)|Net]]||[[File:Trapezo-rhombic dodecahedron flat.png|200px]]
(click to enlarge)
|} In [[geometry]], the '''trapezo-rhombic dodecahedron''' or '''rhombo-trapezoidal dodecahedron''' is a [[convex polygon|convex]] [[dodecahedron]] with 6 [[rhombus|rhombic]] and 6 [[trapezoid|trapezoidal]] faces. It has ''D''''3h'' symmetry. == Construction == This polyhedron could be constructed by taking a tall uniform [[hexagonal prism]], and making 3 angled cuts on the top and bottom. The trapezoids represent what remains of the original prism sides, and the 6 rhombi a result of the top and bottom cuts. == Space-filling tessellation == A [[Honeycomb (geometry)|space-filling tessellation]], the [[trapezo-rhombic dodecahedral honeycomb]], can be made by translated copies of this cell. Each "layer" is a [[hexagonal tiling]], or a [[rhombille tiling]], and alternate layers are connected by shifting their centers and rotating each polyhedron so the rhombic faces match up. :[[File:Trapezo-rhombic_dodecahedron_honeycomb.png|320px]] In the special case that the long sides of the trapezoids equals twice the length of the short sides, the solid now represents the [[Three-dimensional space|3D]] [[Voronoi diagram|Voronoi cell]] of a [[sphere]] in a [[Close-packing of spheres|Hexagonal Close Packing (HCP)]], next to Face-Centered-Cubic an optimal way to stack spheres in a lattice. It is therefore similar to the [[rhombic dodecahedron]], which can be represented by turning the lower half of the picture at right over an angle of 60 degrees. The rhombic dodecahedron is a Voronoi cell of the other optimal way to stack spheres. As the Voronoi cell of a regular space pattern, it is a [[plesiohedron]]. It is the polyhedral [[Dual polyhedron|dual]] of the [[triangular orthobicupola]]. == Variations== The ''trapezo-rhombic dodecahedron'' can be seen as an elongation of another dodecahedron, which can be called a '''rhombo-triangular dodecahedron''', with 6 rhombi (or squares) and 6 triangles. It also has d3h symmetry and is space-filling. It has 21 edges and 11 vertices. With square faces it can be seen as a [[cube]] split across the 3-fold axis, separated with the two halves rotated 180 degrees, and filling the gaps with triangles. When used as a space-filler, connecting dodecahedra on their triangles leaves two cubical step surfaces on the top and bottom which can connect with complimentary steps. {| class=wikitable |[[File:Triangular_square_dodecahedron.png|160px]] |[[File:Triangular_square_dodecahedron_net.png|240px]] |} == See also == * [[Elongated dodecahedron]] * [[Hexagonal prismatic honeycomb]] ==References== * {{The Geometrical Foundation of Natural Structure (book)|page=170}} * ''Mathematical Recreations and Essays'' [[Walter William Rouse Ball]], [[Harold Scott Macdonald Coxeter]], p.151 * ''Structure in Nature Is a Strategy for Design'', [[Peter Jon Pearce]], p.48 Spacefilling systems based on rhombic dodecahedron == External links == * {{mathworld | urlname = Space-FillingPolyhedron | title = Space-filling polyhedron}} * [[VRML]] model [http://www.georgehart.com/virtual-polyhedra/vrml/twisted_rhombic_dodecahedron.wrl] {{Polyhedron-stub}} [[Category:Space-filling polyhedra]]

pages.title: Triakis truncated tetrahedron
pages.text:
{{Distinguish|truncated triakis tetrahedron}} {| class=wikitable align=right width="250" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Triakis truncated tetrahedron |- |align=center colspan=2|[[Image:Triakis truncated tetrahedron.png|240px|Triakis truncated tetrahedron]] [[:File:Triakis truncated tetrahedron.gif|(Click here for rotating model)]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Plesiohedron]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Conway polyhedron notation|Conway notation]]||k3tT |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||4 [[hexagon]]s
12 [[isosceles triangle]]s |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||30 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||16 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Dual||16|[[Order-3 truncated triakis tetrahedron]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Properties||[[Convex polytope|convex]], space-filling |} In [[geometry]], the '''triakis truncated tetrahedron''' is a [[Convex polyhedron|convex]] [[polyhedron]] made from 4 hexagons and 12 isosceles triangles. It can be used to [[Tessellation|tessellate]] three-dimensional space, making the [[triakis truncated tetrahedral honeycomb]].{{cite book|last1=Conway|first1=John H.|last2=Burgiel|first2=Heidi|last3=Goodman-Strauss|first3=Chaim|title=The Symmetries of Things|page=332|year=2008|isbn=978-1568812205}}{{cite journal|last1=Grünbaum|first1=B|last2=Shephard|first2=G. C.|title=Tilings with Congruent Tiles|journal=Bull. Amer. Math. Soc.|volume=3|issue=3|pages=951–973|year=1980|url=http://projecteuclid.org/DPubS?service=UI&version=1.0&verb=Display&handle=euclid.bams/1183547682|doi=10.1090/s0273-0979-1980-14827-2}} The triakis truncated tetrahedron is the shape of the [[Voronoi cell]] of the [[carbon]] atoms in [[diamond]], which lie on the [[diamond cubic]] crystal structure.{{cite journal|first1=L.|last1=Föppl|year=1914|title=Der Fundamentalbereich des Diamantgitters|journal=Phys. Z.|volume=15|pages=191–193}}{{cite web|last=Conway|first=John|title=Voronoi Polyhedron|url=https://groups.google.com/forum/?fromgroups=#!msg/geometry.puzzles/pkL3avbWPoc/ABSaqdQaqu4J|work=geometry.puzzles|accessdate=20 September 2012}} As the Voronoi cell of a symmetric space pattern, it is a [[plesiohedron]].{{citation | last1 = Grünbaum | first1 = Branko | author1-link = Branko Grünbaum | last2 = Shephard | first2 = G. C. | author2-link = Geoffrey Colin Shephard | doi = 10.1090/S0273-0979-1980-14827-2 | issue = 3 | journal = [[Bulletin of the American Mathematical Society]] | mr = 585178 | pages = 951–973 | series = New Series | title = Tilings with congruent tiles | volume = 3 | year = 1980}}. ==Construction== For space-filling, the triakis truncated tetrahedron can be constructed as follows: # Truncate a regular [[tetrahedron]] such that the big faces are regular hexagons. # Add an extra vertex at the center of each of the four smaller tetrahedra that were removed. ==See also== *[[Quarter cubic honeycomb]] *[[Truncated tetrahedron]] *[[Triakis tetrahedron]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Space-filling polyhedra]] [[Category:Truncated tilings]] {{Polyhedron-stub}}

pages.title: Truncated octahedron
pages.text:
{{Semireg polyhedra db|Semireg polyhedron stat table|tO}} In [[geometry]], the '''truncated octahedron''' is an [[Archimedean solid]]. It has 14 faces (8 regular [[hexagon]]al and 6 [[Square (geometry)|square]]), 36 edges, and 24 vertices. Since each of its faces has [[point symmetry]] the truncated octahedron is a [[zonohedron]]. It is also the [[Goldberg polyhedron]] GIV(1,1), containing square and hexagonal faces. Like the cube, it can tessellate (or "pack") 3-dimensional space, as a [[permutohedron]]. Its [[dual polyhedron]] is the [[tetrakis hexahedron]]. If the original truncated octahedron has unit edge length, its dual [[tetrakis cube]] has edge lengths {{sfrac|9|8}}{{sqrt|2}} and {{sfrac|3|2}}{{sqrt|2}}. ==Construction== {| align=center |[[image:Truncated Octahedron with Construction.svg]] |width=50px|  |[[image:Square Pyramid.svg]] |} A truncated octahedron is constructed from a regular [[octahedron]] with side length 3''a'' by the removal of six right [[square pyramid]]s, one from each point. These pyramids have both base side length (''a'') and lateral side length (''e'') of ''a'', to form [[equilateral triangle]]s. The base area is then ''a''2. Note that this shape is exactly similar to half an octahedron or [[Johnson solid]] J1. From the properties of square pyramids, we can now find the slant height, ''s'', and the height, ''h'', of the pyramid: :\begin{align} h &= \sqrt{e^2 - \tfrac{1}{2}a^2} &&= \tfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}a \\ s &= \sqrt{h^2 + \tfrac{1}{4}a^2} &&= \sqrt{\tfrac{1}{2}a^2 + \tfrac{1}{4}a^2} &&= \tfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}a \end{align} The volume, ''V'', of the pyramid is given by: :V = \tfrac{1}{3}a^2h = \tfrac{\sqrt{2}}{6}a^3 Because six pyramids are removed by truncation, there is a total lost volume of {{sqrt|2}}''a''3. ==Orthogonal projections== The ''truncated octahedron'' has five special [[orthogonal projection]]s, centered, on a vertex, on two types of edges, and two types of faces: Hexagon, and square. The last two correspond to the B2 and A2 [[Coxeter plane]]s. {|class=wikitable width=640 |+ Orthogonal projections |- ! Centered by !Vertex !Edge
4-6 !Edge
6-6 !Face
Square !Face
Hexagon |- ! Solid | | |[[File:Polyhedron truncated 8 from blue max.png|100px]] |[[File:Polyhedron truncated 8 from red max.png|100px]] |[[File:Polyhedron truncated 8 from yellow max.png|100px]] |- ! Wireframe |[[File:Cube t12 v.png|100px]] |[[File:Cube t12 e46.png|100px]] |[[File:Cube t12 e66.png|100px]] |[[File:3-cube t12 B2.svg|100px]] |[[File:3-cube t12.svg|100px]] |- ! Dual |[[File:Dual cube t12 v.png|100px]] |[[File:Dual cube t12 e46.png|100px]] |[[File:Dual cube t12 e66.png|100px]] |[[File:Dual cube t12 B2.png|100px]] |[[File:Dual cube t12.png|100px]] |- align=center !Projective
symmetry |[2] |[2] |[2] |[4] |[6] |} ==Spherical tiling== The truncated octahedron can also be represented as a [[spherical tiling]], and projected onto the plane via a [[stereographic projection]]. This projection is [[Conformal map|conformal]], preserving angles but not areas or lengths. Straight lines on the sphere are projected as circular arcs on the plane. {|class=wikitable |- align=center valign=top |[[Image:Uniform tiling 432-t12.png|160px]] |[[Image:truncated octahedron stereographic projection square.png|160px]]
[[square]]-centered |[[Image:truncated octahedron stereographic projection hexagon.png|160px]]
[[hexagon]]-centered |- ![[Orthographic projection]] !colspan=2|[[Stereographic projection]]s |} ==Coordinates == {| class=wikitable width=300 align=right style="margin-left:1em" |[[File:Truncated octahedron in unit cube.png|150px]] |[[File:Triangulated truncated octahedron.png|150px]] |[[File:Rhombic triacontahedron in truncated octahedron.png|150px]] |- valign=top |[[Orthogonal projection]] in [[bounding box]]
(±2,±2,±2) |Truncated octahedron with hexagons replaced by 6 coplanar triangles. There are 8 new vertices at: (±1,±1,±1). |Truncated octahedron subdivided into as a topological [[rhombic triacontahedron]] |} All [[permutation]]s of (0, ±1, ±2) are [[Cartesian coordinates]] of the [[vertex (geometry)|vertices]] of a [[Truncation (geometry)|truncated]] [[octahedron]] of edge length a = √ 2 centered at the origin. The vertices are thus also the corners of 12 rectangles whose long edges are parallel to the coordinate axes. The [[edge vector]]s have Cartesian coordinates {{nowrap|(0, ±1, ±1)}} and permutations of these. The face normals (normalized cross products of edges that share a common vertex) of the 6 square faces are {{nowrap|(0, 0, ±1)}}, {{nowrap|(0, ±1, 0)}} and {{nowrap|(±1, 0, 0)}}. The face normals of the 8 hexagonal faces are {{nowrap|(±{{sfrac|1|{{sqrt|3}}}}, ±{{sfrac|1|{{sqrt|3}}}}, ±{{sfrac|1|{{sqrt|3}}}})}}. The dot product between pairs of two face normals is the cosine of the dihedral angle between adjacent faces, either −{{sfrac|1|3}} or −{{sfrac|1|{{sqrt|3}}}}. The dihedral angle is approximately 1.910633 radians (109.471° {{OEIS2C|A156546}}) at edges shared by two hexagons or 2.186276 radians (125.263° {{OEIS2C|A195698}}) at edges shared by a hexagon and a square. == Dissection == The truncated octahedron can be dissected into a central [[octahedron]], surrounded by 8 [[triangular cupola]] on each face, and 6 [[square pyramid]]s above the vertices.{{cite web|url=http://www.doskey.com/polyhedra/Stewart05.html|title=Adventures Among the Toroids – Chapter 5 – Simplest (R)(A)(Q)(T) Toroids of genus p=1|first=Alex|last=Doskey|date=|website=www.doskey.com}} Removing the central octahedron and 2 or 4 triangular cupola creates two [[Stewart toroid]]s, with dihedral and tetrahedral symmetry: {| class=wikitable !Genus 2 !Genus 3 |- |- valign=top ![[Dihedral symmetry|D3d]], [2+,6], (2*3), order 12 ![[Tetrahedral symmetry|Td]], [3,3], (*332), order 24 |- |[[File:Excavated truncated octahedron1.png|240px]] |[[File:Excavated truncated octahedron2.png|240px]] |} == Permutohedron== The truncated octahedron can also be represented by even more symmetric coordinates in four dimensions: all permutations of (1, 2, 3, 4) form the vertices of a truncated octahedron in the three-dimensional subspace {{nowrap|''x'' + ''y'' + ''z'' + ''w'' {{=}} 10}}. Therefore, the truncated octahedron is the [[permutohedron]] of order 4: each vertex corresponds to a permutation of (1, 2, 3, 4) and each edge represents a single pairwise swap of two elements. [[Image:Permutohedron.svg|300px]] ==Area and volume== The area ''A'' and the [[volume]] ''V'' of a truncated octahedron of edge length ''a'' are: :\begin{align} A &= \left(6+12\sqrt{3}\right) a^2 &&\approx 26.784\,6097a^2 \\ V &= 8\sqrt{2} a^3 &&\approx 11.313\,7085a^3. \end{align} ==Uniform colorings== There are two [[uniform coloring]]s, with [[tetrahedral symmetry]] and [[octahedral symmetry]], and two 2-uniform coloring with [[dihedral symmetry]] as a ''truncated triangular antiprism''. The construcational names are given for each. Their [[Conway polyhedron notation]] is given in parentheses. {|class="wikitable" !colspan=2|1-uniform !colspan=2|2-uniform |- valign=top ![[Octahedral symmetry|Oh]], [4,3], (*432)
Order 48 ![[Tetrahedral symmetry|Td]], [3,3], (*332)
Order 24 ![[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|D4h]], [4,2], (*422)
Order 16 ![[Dihedral symmetry in three dimensions|D3d]], [2+,6], (2*3)
Order 12 |- align=center valign=top |[[File:Uniform polyhedron-43-t12.svg|140px]]
122 coloring |[[File:Uniform polyhedron-33-t012.png|140px]]
123 coloring |[[File:truncated_square_bipyramid.png|140px]]
122 & 322 colorings |[[File:Truncated octahedron prismatic symmetry.png|140px]]
122 & 123 colorings |- !Truncated octahedron
(tO) !Bevelled tetrahedron
(bT) !Truncated square bipyramid
(tdP4) !Truncated triangular antiprism
(tA3) |} == Chemistry== The ''truncated octahedron'' exists in the structure of the [[faujasite]] crystals. :[[File:Sodalit-CageAlSi.png|240px]] ==Related polyhedra== The truncated octahedron is one of a family of uniform polyhedra related to the cube and regular octahedron. {{Octahedral truncations}} It also exists as the omnitruncate of the tetrahedron family: {{Tetrahedron family}} === Symmetry mutations=== {{Omnitruncated table}} {{Omnitruncated_symmetric_table}} This polyhedron is a member of a sequence of uniform patterns with vertex figure (4.6.2''p'') and [[Coxeter–Dynkin diagram]] {{CDD|node_1|p|node_1|3|node_1}}. For ''p'' < 6, the members of the sequence are [[Omnitruncation (geometry)|omnitruncated]] polyhedra ([[zonohedron|zonohedra]]), shown below as spherical tilings. For ''p'' > 6, they are tilings of the hyperbolic plane, starting with the [[truncated triheptagonal tiling]]. The truncated octahedron is topologically related as a part of sequence of uniform polyhedra and tilings with [[vertex figures]] ''n''.6.6, extending into the hyperbolic plane: {{Truncated figure2 table}} The truncated octahedron is topologically related as a part of sequence of uniform polyhedra and tilings with [[vertex figures]] 4.2''n''.2''n'', extending into the hyperbolic plane: {{Truncated figure3 table}} == Related polytopes == The ''[[Truncation (geometry)|truncated]] [[octahedron]]'' ([[bitruncation|bitruncated]] cube), is first in a sequence of bitruncated [[hypercube]]s: {{Bitruncated hypercube polytopes}} ==Tessellations== The truncated octahedron exists in three different [[convex uniform honeycomb]]s ([[Honeycomb (geometry)|space-filling tessellations]]): {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" ![[Bitruncated cubic honeycomb|Bitruncated cubic]] ![[Cantitruncated cubic honeycomb|Cantitruncated cubic]] ![[Truncated alternated cubic honeycomb|Truncated alternated cubic]] |- |align="center"|[[Image:Bitruncated Cubic Honeycomb.svg|150px]] |align="center"|[[Image:Cantitruncated Cubic Honeycomb.svg|150px]] |align="center"|[[Image:Truncated Alternated Cubic Honeycomb.svg|150px]] |} The [[cell-transitive]] [[bitruncated cubic honeycomb]] can also be seen as the [[Voronoi tessellation]] of the [[Crystal structure|body-centered cubic lattice]]. The truncated octahedron is one of five three-dimensional primary [[Parallelohedron#Zonohedra that tile space|parallelohedra]]. ==Objects== {{multiple image | align = right | total_width = 300 | image1 = 43840 Salou, Tarragona, Spain - panoramio (21), crop.jpg | image2 = Bundek climbing frame 20150307 DSC 0109, crop.jpg | footer = [[Jungle gym]] nets often include truncated octahedra. }} 14-sided Chinese dice from warring states period.jpg | ancient Chinese dice CvO 2.jpg | sculpture in [[Bonn]] DaYan Gem solved cubemeister com.jpg | [[Rubik's Cube]] variant Polydron 1170197.jpg | model made with Polydron [[construction set]] Pyrite-249304.jpg | [[Pyrite]] crystal == Truncated octahedral graph == {{Infobox graph | name = Truncated octahedral graph | image = [[File:Truncated octahedral graph2.png|240px]] | image_caption = 3-fold symmetric [[schlegel diagram]] | namesake = | vertices = 24 | edges = 36 | automorphisms = 48 | radius = | diameter = | girth = | chromatic_number = 2 | chromatic_index = | fractional_chromatic_index = | properties = [[Cubic graph|Cubic]], [[hamiltonian graph|Hamiltonian]], [[regular graph|regular]], [[Zero-symmetric graph|zero-symmetric]] |book thickness=3|queue number=2}} In the [[mathematics|mathematical]] field of [[graph theory]], a '''truncated octahedral graph''' is the [[1-skeleton|graph of vertices and edges]] of the truncated octahedron, one of the [[Archimedean solid]]s. It has 24 [[Vertex (graph theory)|vertices]] and 36 edges, and is a [[cubic graph|cubic]] [[Archimedean graph]].{{citation|last1=Read|first1=R. C.|last2=Wilson|first2=R. J.|title=An Atlas of Graphs|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|year= 1998|page=269}} It has [[book thickness]] 3 and [[queue number]] 2.Wolz, Jessica; ''Engineering Linear Layouts with SAT.'' Master Thesis, University of Tübingen, 2018 As a [[Hamiltonian graph|Hamiltonian]] [[cubic graph]], it can be represented by [[LCF notation]] in multiple ways: [3, −7, 7, −3]6, [5, −11, 11, 7, 5, −5, −7, −11, 11, −5, −7, 7]2, and [−11, 5, −3, −7, −9, 3, −5, 5, −3, 9, 7, 3, −5, 11, −3, 7, 5, −7, −9, 9, 7, −5, −7, 3].{{mathworld |urlname=TruncatedOctahedralGraph |title=Truncated octahedral graph}} [[File:Truncated octahedral Hamiltonicity.svg|600px|thumb|left|Three different Hamiltonian cycles described by the three different [[LCF notation]]s for the truncated octahedral graph]] [[File:Truncated octahedral graph.neato.svg|240px]] {{Clear}} ==References== {{Reflist}} *{{The Geometrical Foundation of Natural Structure (book)}} (Section 3–9) *{{cite web |author=Freitas, Robert A., Jr |title=Uniform space-filling using only truncated octahedra |publisher=Figure 5.5 of [http://www.nanomedicine.com/NMI.htm Nanomedicine, Volume I: Basic Capabilities], Landes Bioscience, Georgetown, TX, 1999 |url=http://www.nanomedicine.com/NMI/Figures/5.5.jpg |accessdate=2006-09-08}} *{{cite journal |author1=Gaiha, P. |author2=Guha, S.K. |lastauthoramp=yes |year=1977 |title=Adjacent |url=http://www.mathconsult.ch/showroom/unipoly/08.html |accessdate=2006-09-08}} *{{cite book |author=Alexandrov, A.D. |year=1958 |title=Convex polyhedra |location=Berlin |publisher=Springer
