pages.title: Tiling with rectangles
pages.text:
A '''tiling with rectangles''' is a [[tessellation|tiling]] which uses [[rectangle]]s as its parts. The [[Domino tiling|domino tilings]] are tilings with rectangles of {{math|1 × 2}} side ratio. The tilings with straight [[polyomino]]es of shapes such as {{math|1 × 3}}, {{math|1 × 4}} and tilings with polyominoes of shapes such as {{math|2 × 3}} fall also into this category. == Congruent rectangles == Some tiling of rectangles include: {| class=wikitable |- |[[File:Stacked bond.png|150px]]
Stacked bond |[[File:Wallpaper group-cmm-1.jpg|150px]]
Running bond |[[File:Wallpaper group-p4g-1.jpg|150px]]
[[Basketweave|Basket weave]] |[[File:Basketweave bond.svg|150px]]
Basket weave |[[File:Herringbone bond.svg|150px]]
[[Herringbone pattern]] |} == Tilings with non-congruent rectangles == The smallest square that can be cut into (m × n) rectangles, such that all m and n are different integers, is the 11 × 11 square, and the tiling uses five rectangles.{{cite journal|last1=Madachy|first1=Joseph S.|title=Solutions to Problems and Conjectures |journal=Journal of Recreational Mathematics|date=1998|volume=29|issue=1|page=73|issn=0022-412X}} The smallest rectangle that can be cut into (m × n) rectangles, such that all m and n are different integers, is the 9 × 13 rectangle, and the tiling uses five rectangles. ==See also== * [[Squaring the square]] * [[Tessellation]] * [[Tiling puzzle]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Tessellation]] {{geometry-stub}}

pages.title: Truchet tiles
pages.text: In [[information visualization]] and [[graphic design]], '''Truchet tiles''' are square tiles decorated with patterns that are not [[rotational symmetry|rotationally symmetric]]. When placed in a [[square tiling]] of the plane, they can form varied patterns, and the orientation of each tile can be used to visualize information associated with the tile's position within the tiling.{{citation | last = Browne | first = Cameron | doi = 10.1016/j.cag.2007.10.001 | issue = 2 | journal = Computers & Graphics | pages = 268–281 | title = Truchet curves and surfaces | volume = 32 | year = 2008}}. Truchet tiles were first described in a 1704 memoir by [[Sébastien Truchet]] entitled "Mémoire sur les combinaisons", and were popularized in 1987 by [[Cyril Stanley Smith]].{{citation | last = Smith | first = Cyril Stanley | author-link = Cyril Stanley Smith | doi = 10.2307/1578535 | issue = 4 | journal = [[Leonardo (journal)|Leonardo]] | pages = 373–385 | title = The tiling patterns of Sebastian Truchet and the topology of structural hierarchy | volume = 20 | year = 1987}}. With a translation of Truchet's text by Pauline Boucher. ==Variations== ===Contrasting triangles=== The tile originally studied by Truchet is split along the diagonal into two triangles of contrasting colors. The tile has four possible orientations. [[File:Truchet base tiles bordered.png|center]] Some examples of surface filling made tiling such a [[pattern]]. With a scheme: [[File:Truchet ordered tiling.svg|center]] With random placement: [[File:Truchet base tiling.svg|center|thumb|250px]] ===Quarter-circles=== A second common form of the Truchet tiles, due to {{harvtxt|Smith|1987}}, decorates each tile with two quarter-circles connecting the midpoints of adjacent sides. Each such tile has two possible orientations. {{multiple image | align = center | footer = | width = 120 | image1 = Truchet tile.svg | alt1 = Truchet tile | caption1 = The Truchet tile | image2 = Truchet tile inverse.svg | alt2 = Truchet tile inverse | caption2 = Inverse of the Truchet tile, created by any 90° rotation or orthogonal flip }} We have such a tiling: [[File:Truchet tiling.svg|thumb|center|250px]] This type of tile has also been used in abstract strategy games [[Trax (game)|Trax]] and the [[Black Path Game]], prior to Smith's work. ===Diagonal=== A [[labyrinth]] can be generated by tiles in the form of a white square with a black diagonal. As with the quarter-circle tiles, each such tile has two orientations.{{cite book | url=http://news.mit.edu/2013/10-print-chr2055rnd1-goto-10 | title=10 PRINT CHR$(205.5+RND(1)); : GOTO 10 | publisher=MIT Press | author=Montfort, Nick | year=2012}} The connectivity of the resulting labyrinth can be analyzed mathematically using [[percolation theory]] as bond percolation at the critical point of a diagonally-oriented grid. [[Nick Montfort]] considers the single line of [[Commodore 64]] [[BASIC]] required to generate such patterns - 10 PRINT CHR$(205.5+RND(1)); : GOTO 10 - to be "a [[concrete poetry|concrete poem]], a found poem". [[File:Truchet labyrinth.png|center|thumb|250px|A labyrinth generated from diagonal tiles]] == See also == {{Commonscat|Truchet tiles}} *[[Girih tiles]] *[[Wallpaper group]] *[[Wang tiles]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{mathworld|title=Truchet Tiling|urlname=TruchetTiling}} * Truchet in 2D and 3D: https://web.archive.org/web/20120820024223/http://local.wasp.uwa.edu.au/~pbourke/texture_colour/periodic/ * Javascript animation: http://perso.orange.fr/jean-paul.davalan/divers/truchet/truc.html (unknown page, 19.05.06) {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Tessellation]] [[Category:Patterns]]

pages.title: Voderberg tiling
pages.text:
[[File:Voderberg-1.png|thumb|A partial Voderberg tiling. Note that all of the colored tiles are congruent.]]
The '''Voderberg tiling''' is a mathematical [[spiral]] [[mathematical tiling|tiling]], invented in 1936 by mathematician [[Heinz Voderberg]].<ref name=mbook>{{cite book |last=Pickover |first=Clifford A. |date=2009 |title=The Math Book: From Pythagoras to the 57th Dimension, 250 Milestones in the History of Mathematics |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JrslMKTgSZwC |publisher=Sterling Publishing Company, Inc. |page=372 |isbn=9781402757969 |access-date=24 March 2015 }}</ref> It is a monohedral tiling, meaning that it consists of only one shape, tessellated with congruent copies of itself. In this case, the [[prototile]] is an elongated irregular [[enneagon]], or nine-sided figure. Because it has no [[translational symmetries]], the Voderberg tiling is technically [[aperiodic tiling|non-periodic]], even though it exhibits an obvious repeating pattern. 

This tiling was the first spiral tiling to be devised,<ref name="special">{{cite web | url=https://www.uwgb.edu/dutchs/symmetry/radspir1.htm | title=Some Special Radial and Spiral Tilings | publisher=University of Wisconsin, Green Bay | date=29 July 1999 | accessdate=24 March 2015 | author=Dutch, Steven | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305011416/https://www.uwgb.edu/dutchs/symmetry/radspir1.htm | archive-date=5 March 2016 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref> preceding later work by [[Branko Grünbaum]] and [[Geoffrey C. Shephard]] in the 1970s.<ref name=mbook /> A Voderberg tiling is depicted on the cover of Grünbaum and Shephard's  1987 book ''Tilings and Patterns''.<ref>{{citation
 | last1 = Grünbaum | first1 = Branko
 | last2 = Shephard | first2 = G. C.
 | isbn = 0-7167-1193-1
 | location = New York
 | publisher = W. H. Freeman
 | title = Tilings and Patterns
 | year = 1987
 | at = Section 9.5, "Spiral Tilings," p. 512}}.</ref>

{{Commons category|Voderberg spiral tiling}}

pages.title: Order-3-4 heptagonal honeycomb
pages.text:
{| class="wikitable" align="right" style="margin-left:10px" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Order-3-4 heptagonal honeycomb |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[List of regular polytopes#Tessellations of hyperbolic 3-space|Regular honeycomb]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Schläfli symbol]]||{7,3,4} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter diagram]]||{{CDD|node_1|7|node|3|node|4|node}}
{{CDD|node_1|7|node|3|node|4|node_h0}} = {{CDD|node_1|7|node|split1|nodes}} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Cells||[[heptagonal tiling|{7,3}]] [[File:Heptagonal tiling.svg|80px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||[[Heptagon]] {7} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Vertex figure]]||[[octahedron]] {3,4} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Dual||[[Order-7 cubic honeycomb|{4,3,7}]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter–Dynkin diagram#Ranks 4.E2.80.9310|Coxeter group]]||[7,3,4] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Properties||Regular |} In the [[geometry]] of [[Hyperbolic space|hyperbolic 3-space]], the '''order-3-4 heptagonal honeycomb''' or '''7,3,4 honeycomb''' a regular space-filling [[tessellation]] (or [[honeycomb (geometry)|honeycomb]]). Each infinite cell consists of a [[heptagonal tiling]] whose vertices lie on a [[Hypercycle (geometry)|2-hypercycle]], each of which has a limiting circle on the ideal sphere. == Geometry == The [[Schläfli symbol]] of the order-3-4 heptagonal honeycomb is {7,3,4}, with four [[heptagonal tiling]]s meeting at each edge. The [[vertex figure]] of this honeycomb is an octahedron, {3,4}. {| class=wikitable width=600 |[[File:Hyperbolic honeycomb 7-3-4 poincare vc.png|200px]]
[[Poincaré disk model]]
(vertex centered) |[[File:Order-3-4_heptagonal_honeycomb_cell.png|200px]]
One hyperideal cell limits to a circle on the ideal surface |[[File:H3_734_UHS_plane_at_infinity.png|200px]]
Ideal surface |} == Related polytopes and honeycombs == It is a part of a series of regular polytopes and honeycombs with {p,3,4} [[Schläfli symbol]], and octahedral [[vertex figures]]: {{Octahedral_vertex_figure_tessellations}} {{-}} === Order-3-4 octagonal honeycomb=== {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="margin-left:10px" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Order-3-4 octagonal honeycomb |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[List of regular polytopes#Tessellations of hyperbolic 3-space|Regular honeycomb]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Schläfli symbol]]||{8,3,4} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter diagram]]||{{CDD|node_1|8|node|3|node|4|node}}
{{CDD|node_1|8|node|3|node|4|node_h0}} = {{CDD|node_1|8|node|split1|nodes}}
{{CDD|node|ultra|node_1|split1-44|branch_11|label4|uaub|nodes}}
{{CDD|node_1|ultra|node_1|split1-44|branch_11|label4|uaub|nodes_11}} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Cells||[[heptagonal tiling|{8,3}]] [[File:H2_tiling_238-1.png|80px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||[[Octagon]] {8} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Vertex figure]]||[[octahedron]] {3,4} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Dual||[[Order-8 cubic honeycomb|{4,3,8}]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter–Dynkin diagram#Ranks 4.E2.80.9310|Coxeter group]]||[8,3,4]
[8,31,1] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Properties||Regular |} In the [[geometry]] of [[Hyperbolic space|hyperbolic 3-space]], the '''order-3-4 octagonal honeycomb''' or '''8,3,4 honeycomb''' a regular space-filling [[tessellation]] (or [[honeycomb (geometry)|honeycomb]]). Each infinite cell consists of an [[octagonal tiling]] whose vertices lie on a [[Hypercycle (geometry)|2-hypercycle]], each of which has a limiting circle on the ideal sphere. The [[Schläfli symbol]] of the ''order-3-4 octagonal honeycomb'' is {8,3,4}, with four octagonal tilings meeting at each edge. The [[vertex figure]] of this honeycomb is an octahedron, {3,4}. {| class=wikitable |[[File:Hyperbolic honeycomb 8-3-4 poincare vc.png|240px]]
[[Poincaré disk model]]
(vertex centered) |} {{-}} === Order-3-4 apeirogonal honeycomb=== {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="margin-left:10px" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Order-3-4 apeirogonal honeycomb |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[List of regular polytopes#Tessellations of hyperbolic 3-space|Regular honeycomb]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Schläfli symbol]]||{∞,3,4} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter diagram]]||{{CDD|node_1|infin|node|3|node|4|node}}
{{CDD|node_1|infin|node|3|node|4|node_h0}} = {{CDD|node_1|infin|node|split1|nodes}}
{{CDD|node|ultra|node_1|split1-ii|branch_11|labelinfin|uaub|nodes}}
{{CDD|node_1|ultra|node_1|split1-ii|branch_11|labelinfin|uaub|nodes_11}} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Cells||[[Order-3 apeirogonal tiling|{∞,3}]] [[File:H2_tiling_23i-1.png|80px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||[[Apeirogon]] {∞} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Vertex figure]]||[[octahedron]] {3,4} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Dual||[[Infinite-order cubic honeycomb|{4,3,∞}]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter–Dynkin diagram#Ranks 4.E2.80.9310|Coxeter group]]||[∞,3,4]
[∞,31,1] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Properties||Regular |} In the [[geometry]] of [[Hyperbolic space|hyperbolic 3-space]], the '''order-3-4 apeirogonal honeycomb''' or '''∞,3,4 honeycomb''' a regular space-filling [[tessellation]] (or [[honeycomb (geometry)|honeycomb]]). Each infinite cell consists of an [[order-3 apeirogonal tiling]] whose vertices lie on a [[Hypercycle (geometry)|2-hypercycle]], each of which has a limiting circle on the ideal sphere. The [[Schläfli symbol]] of the ''order-3-4 apeirogonal honeycomb'' is {∞,3,4}, with four order-3 apeirogonal tilings meeting at each edge. The [[vertex figure]] of this honeycomb is an [[octahedron]], {3,4}. {| class=wikitable |[[File:Hyperbolic honeycomb i-3-4 poincare vc.png|240px]]
[[Poincaré disk model]]
(vertex centered) |[[File:H3_i34_UHS_plane_at_infinity.png|240px]]
Ideal surface |} == See also == * [[Convex uniform honeycombs in hyperbolic space]] * [[List of regular polytopes]] == References == {{reflist}} *[[H. S. M. Coxeter|Coxeter]], ''[[Regular Polytopes (book)|Regular Polytopes]]'', 3rd. ed., Dover Publications, 1973. {{ISBN|0-486-61480-8}}. (Tables I and II: Regular polytopes and honeycombs, pp. 294–296) * ''The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays'' (1999), Dover Publications, {{LCCN|99035678}}, {{ISBN|0-486-40919-8}} (Chapter 10, [http://www.mathunion.org/ICM/ICM1954.3/Main/icm1954.3.0155.0169.ocr.pdf Regular Honeycombs in Hyperbolic Space]) Table III * [[Jeffrey Weeks (mathematician)|Jeffrey R. Weeks]] ''The Shape of Space, 2nd edition'' {{ISBN|0-8247-0709-5}} (Chapters 16–17: Geometries on Three-manifolds I,II) * George Maxwell, ''Sphere Packings and Hyperbolic Reflection Groups'', JOURNAL OF ALGEBRA 79,78-97 (1982) [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0021869382903180] * Hao Chen, Jean-Philippe Labbé, ''Lorentzian Coxeter groups and Boyd-Maxwell ball packings'', (2013)[https://arxiv.org/abs/1310.8608] * [https://arxiv.org/abs/1511.02851 Visualizing Hyperbolic Honeycombs arXiv:1511.02851] Roice Nelson, Henry Segerman (2015) == External links == *[[John Baez]], ''Visual insights'': [http://blogs.ams.org/visualinsight/2014/08/01/733-honeycomb/ {7,3,3} Honeycomb] (2014/08/01) [http://blogs.ams.org/visualinsight/2014/08/14/733-honeycomb-meets-plane-at-infinity/ {7,3,3} Honeycomb Meets Plane at Infinity] (2014/08/14) * [[Danny Calegari]], [http://lamington.wordpress.com/2014/03/04/kleinian-a-tool-for-visualizing-kleinian-groups/Kleinian Kleinian, a tool for visualizing Kleinian groups, Geometry and the Imagination] 4 March 2014. [http://math.uchicago.edu/~dannyc/papers/kleinian_mtf_Feb_2014.pdf] [[Category:Honeycombs (geometry)]] [[Category:Heptagonal tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal 3-honeycombs]] [[Category:Isochoric 3-honeycombs]] [[Category:Order-3-n 3-honeycombs]] [[Category:Order-n-4 3-honeycombs]] [[Category:Regular 3-honeycombs]]

pages.text:
{| class="wikitable" align="right" style="margin-left:10px" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Order-3-5 heptagonal honeycomb |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[List of regular polytopes#Tessellations of hyperbolic 3-space|Regular honeycomb]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Schläfli symbol]]||{7,3,5} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter diagram]]||{{CDD|node_1|7|node|3|node|5|node}} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Cells||[[heptagonal tiling|{7,3}]] [[File:Heptagonal tiling.svg|80px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||[[Heptagon]] {7} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Vertex figure]]||[[icosahedron]] {3,5} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Dual||[[Order-7 cubic honeycomb|{5,3,7}]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter–Dynkin diagram#Ranks 4.E2.80.9310|Coxeter group]]||[7,3,5] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Properties||Regular |} In the [[geometry]] of [[Hyperbolic space|hyperbolic 3-space]], the '''order-3-5 heptagonal honeycomb''' a regular space-filling [[tessellation]] (or [[honeycomb (geometry)|honeycomb]]). Each infinite cell consists of a [[heptagonal tiling]] whose vertices lie on a [[Hypercycle (geometry)|2-hypercycle]], each of which has a limiting circle on the ideal sphere. == Geometry == The [[Schläfli symbol]] of the order-3-5 heptagonal honeycomb is {7,3,5}, with five heptagonal tilings meeting at each edge. The [[vertex figure]] of this honeycomb is an icosahedron, {3,5}. {| class=wikitable |[[File:Hyperbolic honeycomb 7-3-5 poincare vc.png|240px]]
[[Poincaré disk model]]
(vertex centered) |[[File:H3_735_UHS_plane_at_infinity.png|240px]]
Ideal surface |} == Related polytopes and honeycombs == It is a part of a series of regular polytopes and honeycombs with {p,3,5} [[Schläfli symbol]], and icosahedral [[vertex figures]]. {{Icosahedral vertex figure tessellations}} {{-}} === Order-3-5 octagonal honeycomb=== {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="margin-left:10px" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Order-3-5 octagonal honeycomb |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[List of regular polytopes#Tessellations of hyperbolic 3-space|Regular honeycomb]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Schläfli symbol]]||{8,3,5} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter diagram]]||{{CDD|node_1|8|node|3|node|5|node}} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Cells||[[octagonal tiling|{8,3}]] [[File:H2_tiling_238-1.png|80px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||[[Octagon]] {8} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Vertex figure]]||[[icosahedron]] {3,5} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Dual||[[Order-8 dodecahedral honeycomb|{5,3,8}]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter–Dynkin diagram#Ranks 4.E2.80.9310|Coxeter group]]||[8,3,5] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Properties||Regular |} In the [[geometry]] of [[Hyperbolic space|hyperbolic 3-space]], the '''order-3-5 octagonal honeycomb''' a regular space-filling [[tessellation]] (or [[honeycomb (geometry)|honeycomb]]). Each infinite cell consists of a [[octagonal tiling]] whose vertices lie on a [[Hypercycle (geometry)|2-hypercycle]], each of which has a limiting circle on the ideal sphere. The [[Schläfli symbol]] of the order 3-5 heptagonal honeycomb is {8,3,5}, with five octagonal tilings meeting at each edge. The [[vertex figure]] of this honeycomb is an icosahedron, {3,5}. {| class=wikitable |[[File:Hyperbolic honeycomb 8-3-5 poincare vc.png|240px]]
[[Poincaré disk model]]
(vertex centered) |} {{-}} === Order-3-5 apeirogonal honeycomb=== {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="margin-left:10px" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Order-3-5 apeirogonal honeycomb |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[List of regular polytopes#Tessellations of hyperbolic 3-space|Regular honeycomb]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Schläfli symbol]]||{∞,3,5} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter diagram]]||{{CDD|node_1|infin|node|3|node|5|node}} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Cells||[[Order-3 apeirogonal tiling|{∞,3}]] [[File:H2_tiling_23i-1.png|80px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||[[Apeirogon]] {∞} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Vertex figure]]||[[icosahedron]] {3,5} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Dual||[[Infinite-order cubic honeycomb|{5,3,∞}]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter–Dynkin diagram#Ranks 4.E2.80.9310|Coxeter group]]||[∞,3,5] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Properties||Regular |} In the [[geometry]] of [[Hyperbolic space|hyperbolic 3-space]], the '''order-3-5 apeirogonal honeycomb''' a regular space-filling [[tessellation]] (or [[honeycomb (geometry)|honeycomb]]). Each infinite cell consists of an [[order-3 apeirogonal tiling]] whose vertices lie on a [[Hypercycle (geometry)|2-hypercycle]], each of which has a limiting circle on the ideal sphere. The [[Schläfli symbol]] of the order-3-5 apeirogonal honeycomb is {∞,3,5}, with five order-3 apeirogonal tilings meeting at each edge. The [[vertex figure]] of this honeycomb is an [[icosahedron]], {3,5}. {| class=wikitable |[[File:Hyperbolic honeycomb i-3-5 poincare vc.png|240px]]
[[Poincaré disk model]]
(vertex centered) |[[File:H3_i35_UHS_plane_at_infinity.png|240px]]
Ideal surface |} == See also == * [[Convex uniform honeycombs in hyperbolic space]] * [[List of regular polytopes]] == References == {{reflist}} *[[H. S. M. Coxeter|Coxeter]], ''[[Regular Polytopes (book)|Regular Polytopes]]'', 3rd. ed., Dover Publications, 1973. {{ISBN|0-486-61480-8}}. (Tables I and II: Regular polytopes and honeycombs, pp. 294–296) * ''The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays'' (1999), Dover Publications, {{LCCN|99035678}}, {{ISBN|0-486-40919-8}} (Chapter 10, [http://www.mathunion.org/ICM/ICM1954.3/Main/icm1954.3.0155.0169.ocr.pdf Regular Honeycombs in Hyperbolic Space]) Table III * [[Jeffrey Weeks (mathematician)|Jeffrey R. Weeks]] ''The Shape of Space, 2nd edition'' {{ISBN|0-8247-0709-5}} (Chapters 16–17: Geometries on Three-manifolds I,II) * George Maxwell, ''Sphere Packings and Hyperbolic Reflection Groups'', JOURNAL OF ALGEBRA 79,78-97 (1982) [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0021869382903180] * Hao Chen, Jean-Philippe Labbé, ''Lorentzian Coxeter groups and Boyd-Maxwell ball packings'', (2013)[https://arxiv.org/abs/1310.8608] * [https://arxiv.org/abs/1511.02851 Visualizing Hyperbolic Honeycombs arXiv:1511.02851] Roice Nelson, Henry Segerman (2015) == External links == *[[John Baez]], ''Visual insights'': [http://blogs.ams.org/visualinsight/2014/08/01/733-honeycomb/ {7,3,3} Honeycomb] (2014/08/01) [http://blogs.ams.org/visualinsight/2014/08/14/733-honeycomb-meets-plane-at-infinity/ {7,3,3} Honeycomb Meets Plane at Infinity] (2014/08/14) * [[Danny Calegari]], [http://lamington.wordpress.com/2014/03/04/kleinian-a-tool-for-visualizing-kleinian-groups/Kleinian Kleinian, a tool for visualizing Kleinian groups, Geometry and the Imagination] 4 March 2014. [http://math.uchicago.edu/~dannyc/papers/kleinian_mtf_Feb_2014.pdf] [[Category:Honeycombs (geometry)]] [[Category:Heptagonal tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal 3-honeycombs]] [[Category:Isochoric 3-honeycombs]] [[Category:Order-3-n 3-honeycombs]] [[Category:Order-n-5 3-honeycombs]] [[Category:Regular 3-honeycombs]]

pages.title: Order-3-6 heptagonal honeycomb
pages.text:
{| class="wikitable" align="right" style="margin-left:10px" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Order-3-6 heptagonal honeycomb |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[List of regular polytopes#Tessellations of hyperbolic 3-space|Regular honeycomb]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Schläfli symbol]]||{7,3,6}
{7,3[3]} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter diagram]]||{{CDD|node_1|7|node|3|node|6|node}}
{{CDD|node_1|7|node|3|node|6|node_h0}} = {{CDD|node_1|7|node|split1|branch}} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Cells||[[heptagonal tiling|{7,3}]] [[File:Heptagonal tiling.svg|80px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||[[Heptagon|{7}]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Vertex figure]]||[[triangular tiling|{3,6}]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Dual||[[Order-3-7 hexagonal honeycomb|{6,3,7}]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter–Dynkin diagram#Ranks 4.E2.80.9310|Coxeter group]]||[7,3,6]
[7,3[3]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Properties||Regular |} In the [[geometry]] of [[Hyperbolic space|hyperbolic 3-space]], the '''order-3-6 heptagonal honeycomb''' a regular space-filling [[tessellation]] (or [[honeycomb (geometry)|honeycomb]]). Each infinite cell consists of a [[heptagonal tiling]] whose vertices lie on a [[Hypercycle (geometry)|2-hypercycle]], each of which has a limiting circle on the ideal sphere. == Geometry == The [[Schläfli symbol]] of the ''order-3-6 heptagonal honeycomb'' is {7,3,6}, with six heptagonal tilings meeting at each edge. The [[vertex figure]] of this honeycomb is an triangular tiling, {3,6}. It has a [[quasiregular polytope|quasiregular]] construction, {{CDD|node_1|7|node|split1|branch}}, which can be seen as alternately colored cells. {| class=wikitable |[[File:Hyperbolic honeycomb 7-3-6 poincare.png|240px]]
[[Poincaré disk model]] |[[File:H3_736_UHS_plane_at_infinity.png|240px]]
Ideal surface |} == Related polytopes and honeycombs == It is a part of a series of regular polytopes and honeycombs with {p,3,6} [[Schläfli symbol]], and [[triangular tiling]] [[vertex figures]]. {{Triangular_tiling_vertex_figure_tessellations}} === Order-3-6 octagonal honeycomb=== {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="margin-left:10px" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Order-3-6 octagonal honeycomb |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[List of regular polytopes#Tessellations of hyperbolic 3-space|Regular honeycomb]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Schläfli symbol]]||{8,3,6}
{8,3[3]} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter diagram]]||{{CDD|node_1|8|node|3|node|6|node}}
{{CDD|node_1|8|node|3|node|6|node_h0}} = {{CDD|node_1|8|node|split1|branch}} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Cells||[[octagonal tiling|{8,3}]] [[File:H2_tiling_238-1.png|80px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||[[Octagon]] {8} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Vertex figure]]||[[triangular tiling]] {3,6} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Dual||[[Order-8 dodecahedral honeycomb|{6,3,8}]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter–Dynkin diagram#Ranks 4.E2.80.9310|Coxeter group]]||[8,3,6]
[8,3[3]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Properties||Regular |} In the [[geometry]] of [[Hyperbolic space|hyperbolic 3-space]], the '''order-3-6 octagonal honeycomb''' a regular space-filling [[tessellation]] (or [[honeycomb (geometry)|honeycomb]]). Each infinite cell consists of an [[order-6 octagonal tiling]] whose vertices lie on a [[Hypercycle (geometry)|2-hypercycle]], each of which has a limiting circle on the ideal sphere. The [[Schläfli symbol]] of the ''order-3-6 octagonal honeycomb'' is {8,3,6}, with six octagonal tilings meeting at each edge. The [[vertex figure]] of this honeycomb is a triangular tiling, {3,6}. It has a [[quasiregular polytope|quasiregular]] construction, {{CDD|node_1|8|node|split1|branch}}, which can be seen as alternately colored cells. {| class=wikitable |[[File:Hyperbolic honeycomb 8-3-6 poincare.png|240px]]
[[Poincaré disk model]] |} {{-}} === Order-3-6 apeirogonal honeycomb=== {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="margin-left:10px" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Order-3-6 apeirogonal honeycomb |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[List of regular polytopes#Tessellations of hyperbolic 3-space|Regular honeycomb]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Schläfli symbol]]||{∞,3,6}
{∞,3[3]} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter diagram]]||{{CDD|node_1|infin|node|3|node|6|node}}
{{CDD|node_1|infin|node|3|node|6|node_h0}} = {{CDD|node_1|infin|node|split1|branch}} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Cells||[[Order-3 apeirogonal tiling|{∞,3}]] [[File:H2_tiling_23i-1.png|80px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||[[Apeirogon]] {∞} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Vertex figure]]||[[triangular tiling]] {3,6} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Dual||[[Infinite-order cubic honeycomb|{6,3,∞}]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter–Dynkin diagram#Ranks 4.E2.80.9310|Coxeter group]]||[∞,3,6]
[∞,3[3]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Properties||Regular |} In the [[geometry]] of [[Hyperbolic space|hyperbolic 3-space]], the '''order-3-6 apeirogonal honeycomb''' a regular space-filling [[tessellation]] (or [[honeycomb (geometry)|honeycomb]]). Each infinite cell consists of an [[order-3 apeirogonal tiling]] whose vertices lie on a [[Hypercycle (geometry)|2-hypercycle]], each of which has a limiting circle on the ideal sphere. The [[Schläfli symbol]] of the order-3-6 apeirogonal honeycomb is {∞,3,6}, with six ''order-3 apeirogonal tilings'' meeting at each edge. The [[vertex figure]] of this honeycomb is a [[triangular tiling]], {3,6}. {| class=wikitable |[[File:Hyperbolic honeycomb i-3-6 poincare.png|240px]]
[[Poincaré disk model]] |[[File:H3_i36_UHS_plane_at_infinity.png|240px]]
Ideal surface |} It has a [[quasiregular polytope|quasiregular]] construction, {{CDD|node_1|infin|node|split1|branch}}, which can be seen as alternately colored cells. == See also == * [[Convex uniform honeycombs in hyperbolic space]] * [[List of regular polytopes]] == References == {{reflist}} *[[H. S. M. Coxeter|Coxeter]], ''[[Regular Polytopes (book)|Regular Polytopes]]'', 3rd. ed., Dover Publications, 1973. {{ISBN|0-486-61480-8}}. (Tables I and II: Regular polytopes and honeycombs, pp. 294–296) * ''The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays'' (1999), Dover Publications, {{LCCN|99035678}}, {{ISBN|0-486-40919-8}} (Chapter 10, [http://www.mathunion.org/ICM/ICM1954.3/Main/icm1954.3.0155.0169.ocr.pdf Regular Honeycombs in Hyperbolic Space]) Table III * [[Jeffrey Weeks (mathematician)|Jeffrey R. Weeks]] ''The Shape of Space, 2nd edition'' {{ISBN|0-8247-0709-5}} (Chapters 16–17: Geometries on Three-manifolds I,II) * George Maxwell, ''Sphere Packings and Hyperbolic Reflection Groups'', JOURNAL OF ALGEBRA 79,78-97 (1982) [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0021869382903180] * Hao Chen, Jean-Philippe Labbé, ''Lorentzian Coxeter groups and Boyd-Maxwell ball packings'', (2013)[https://arxiv.org/abs/1310.8608] * [https://arxiv.org/abs/1511.02851 Visualizing Hyperbolic Honeycombs arXiv:1511.02851] Roice Nelson, Henry Segerman (2015) == External links == *[[John Baez]], ''Visual insights'': [http://blogs.ams.org/visualinsight/2014/08/01/733-honeycomb/ {7,3,3} Honeycomb] (2014/08/01) [http://blogs.ams.org/visualinsight/2014/08/14/733-honeycomb-meets-plane-at-infinity/ {7,3,3} Honeycomb Meets Plane at Infinity] (2014/08/14) * [[Danny Calegari]], [http://lamington.wordpress.com/2014/03/04/kleinian-a-tool-for-visualizing-kleinian-groups/Kleinian Kleinian, a tool for visualizing Kleinian groups, Geometry and the Imagination] 4 March 2014.
